title: Pot exhibit: Oakland Museum announces plans for 'Altered State: Marijuana in California'
text:
Pot exhibit: Oakland Museum announces plans for 'Altered State: Marijuana in California' By Martha Ross Posted: 10/01/2015 02:18:56 PM PDT Updated: 10/01/2015 02:18:57 PM PDT By Martha Ross 
mross@bayareanewsgroup.com 
Colorado might have been the first state to make pot legal for recreational use, but California will have a marijuana first of its own -- the first-ever museum exhibit on the subject. 
The Oakland Museum of California announced today that "Altered State: Marijuana in California," slated to open in April 2016, will delve into the history, politics, criminalization, science and business surrounding "the evil weed" or "sacred ganja." 
The exhibit, which will be on display as an initiative campaign tries to make recreational marijuana use legal in California in 2016, will explore marijuana's uses and society's evolving and complex attitudes surrounding it. Specific topics include medical cannabis, pot's role in creative thinking (or in its demise), its potential as a major U.S. industry, and long-standing views that it's a gateway drug that leads young people into addiction, crime and despair. 
"California is on the verge of making important decisions around marijuana that will impact people living in this state," says Kelly McKinley, Director of the OMCA Lab. "OMCA is a place where people can come together to learn, question, and add their voice to the different points of view around this topic at a very critical time in public decision making." The exhibition will explore these topics with interactive displays using data, expert voices and diverse viewpoints. 
"Altered States" runs April 16-September 25 in this museum's Great Hall, http://museumca.org .
